page.name: Topic 3.3: Supporting your participants
page.content:
Overview

High-quality pre-apprenticeships do more than teach skills; they also deliver Support Services to help their Participants overcome barriers to completing a pre-apprenticeship — such as lack of access to childcare, elder care, transportation, or mental health support services.

The resources below outline strategies different pre-apprenticeship programs have implemented to support their participants. This may give you some ideas, but it will be important that you deliver support services that are tailored to your specific target participants. 

If you think you will need to partner with another organization to deliver support services, consider revisiting the resources around industry partnerships from Topic 2.2: Partnering with employers and apprenticeships — these are also relevant to other types of partnerships.

Recommended reading

  • 4 strategies for incorporating equity and diversity in your apprenticeship program (JFF). This resource provides tips on creating an inclusive apprenticeship program — including through recruitment, flexible and responsive training, and post-completion support. These principles can be applied to pre-apprenticeships.
  • Strengthening supports for people with disabilities in pre-apprenticeships (Office of Disability Employment Policy, U.S. Department of Labor). This brief outlines strategies to help make pre-apprenticeships more inclusive and accessible for youth and adults with disabilities.
  • Examples: pre-apprenticeship and apprenticeship retention practices (U.S. Department of Labor). This document provides a brief overview of effective strategies to support pre-apprenticeship participants and graduates, including alumni groups and events.
  • Broadening the apprenticeship pipeline (National Skills Coalition). Pages 3-7 of this brief explore the importance of affordable childcare in supporting access to and completion of pre-apprenticeships. In reading this, consider whether childcare may be a need for your participants.
Case studies 
  • Construction pre-apprenticeship programs (Aspen Institute). Read pages 11-12 of this report to learn more about the different support services offered by construction pre-apprenticeships. Note how programs identify the barriers their participants face and provide support to overcome them.
  • Building a statewide system of High Road pre-apprenticeship in California (California Workforce Development Board). This report illustrates the importance of integrating support services from recruitment through to placement and beyond. Read pages 22-29 to learn about promising practices from several training partnerships in California.

Recommended viewing

  • Women in skilled manufacturing apprenticeships and careers: an introduction to equity and inclusion (Jobs for the Future). The recordings of this two-day virtual institute include discussions with experts around best practices for hiring, training, and retaining women in manufacturing.

Helpful tools

  • Job Accommodation Network (Office of Disability Employment Policy, U.S. Department of Labor). A source of free and confidential guidance on workplace accommodations and disability employment.
  • Pre-apprenticeship program case file checklist (U.S. Department of Labor). This checklist will give you an idea of the types of information you need to collect in order to monitor and support your participants.
